response.answer_text: There are two different things that people call “streaming” these days. Online radio (which is the actual “streaming”). On the remote machine a special software (e.g., Icecast, SHOUTcast, ffserver) continuously generates what you can think of as an “infinite .mp3 file”. You, as a listener, can access that “file” (= “stream”) using a URL. E.g., this URL – http://ice1.somafm.com/thetrip-128-mp3 – gives you a stream of SomaFM’s The Trip channel. So, for you it’s essentially an .mp3 file which is located somewhere remotely, and which you have no control of – you cannot rewind it back or forward, you can just click “play” and listen to whatever it is currently playing there. All the listeners who open the same URL will listen to the same music as it’s generated per URL, not per listener.Online streaming service (which we call that way, but what technically might not be 100% correct). This is how Pandora, Spotify, Google Music and all the other similar services work. The remote software sends you (to your client app or a web browser) a URL t a song (an .mp3 file). Your client app downloads and plays that .mp3 file for you, then asks the remote software to provide a link to the next file to download and play. And so forth. Every time when the remote program receives a request for the next song, it can decide which one to provide (taking into account tons of parameters – user’s location, genre preferences, trending songs, user’s age, etc.) and in most cases it will differ for different users. For example, if you open Tuneself Radio (which is actually not a radio) and click “next” button a few times, you will get some music, but the songs will be most likely different from those which I get if I do the same at the same time. From the given example, you can also see that in the case of a “streaming service”, you may have some control of what is playing and how (typically, you can rewind across the currently playing song – as it’s basically “an .mp3 file in your player” – and advance to the next song).PS I used “.mp3 file” term for simplicity, the actual audio format may be different for both online radio streams and streaming services (not necessarily MP3 per se).
